results.title: National Velvet (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Clarence Brown, Pandro S. Berman and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Based on the novel “National Velvet” by Enid Bagnold, this is the incredible story of a girl who rides to victory in the celebrated Grand National at Aintree, England. Velvet Brown, a young girl passionately interested in horses wins a horse in a raffle and with the help of Mi, an ex-jockey, sets out to win the greatest steeplechase in the world, the Grand National. Stars Elizabeth Taylor and Mickey Rooney. Rated: G

results.title: The Adventures of Marco Polo
results.creator_credit: Archie Mayo, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Productions
results.brief_description: Gary Cooper stars as 13th Century explorer and adventurer Marco Polo, the Venetian who opened the trade route from Europe to China. At the court of the great Kublai Khan, ruler of the Mongol Empire, Marco battles the intrigue of the court to win the admiration of the great Khan and the love of a beautiful Princess (Sigrid Guthrie). A classic historical drama filled with spectacular battle scenes, panoramas, opulent sets and costumes. Co-starring Basil Rathbone.

results.title: Billy Liar
results.creator_credit: John Schlesinger, Joseph Janni, Vic Films and Waterhall Productions
results.brief_description: Billy Fisher lives in the rich and escapist world of his wild imagination. An irresponsible clerk in a north country town, Billy is unable to tell the truth even for two minutes. In his fantasies, Billy is a successful man of the world; in reality he gets into one scrape after another. Unable to communicate with his parents, engaged to two girls at the same time and dreaming of being a writer, Billy’s life becomes almost unbearable. Into this picture enters Liz. Her free spirit and appreciation of the creativity behind the day-dreams, offers Billy the possibility of escape. Tom Courtenay is Billy and Julie Christie is Liz in what is recognised as one of the landmark films of its decade.

results.title: Guys and dolls
results.creator_credit: Joseph L Mankiewicz, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Productions
results.brief_description: Adapted from a short story by Damon Runyan about a pair of ne’er to do gamblers trying to snare a jackpot amidst the clutter of Times Square as well as the affections of two women. The excellent score by Frank Loesser includes “Luck be a lady”, “If I were a bell” and Stubby Kaye’s show stopper “Sitdown, you’re rocking the boat.” Choreographer Michale Kidd brought the dances full of flash and vitality to the screen. Starring Marlon Brando, Frank Sinatra, Jean Simmons and Vivian Blaine.

results.title: The Nutty professor
results.creator_credit: Jerry Lewis, Ernest D Glucksman and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Professor Julius F. Kelp (Jerry Lewis), is a chemistry teacher in a large university. Tired of being pushed around and humiliated, he dedicates himself to finding a scientific solution to his problem and discovers a chemical formula that transforms him from a clumsy, shy weakling into an irresistable, dynamic individual, called Buddy Love. However the potion often wears off at inappropriate times with embarrassing and hilarious results. Julius finds himself juggling a hectic doublelife, meek chemistry professor by day, local celebrity and heart throb by night. Inevitably these two worlds collide. Written and directed by Jerry Lewis, this madcap comedy is a swinging combination of farce, slapstick and romance.

results.title: Captains Courageous
results.creator_credit: Louis D Lighton, Victor Fleming and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This superb adaptation of Rudyard Kipling’s poignant masterpiece, set on the high seas stars Spencer Tracy as Manuel, the Portugese fisherman who teaches human values to a spoilt millionaire’s son, won him the Best Actor Oscar. The impressive cast also includes Mickey Rooney, Lionel Barrymore and Melvyn Douglas. Twelve year old Harvey Cheyne (Freddie Bartholomew) is travelling with his father aboard an ocean liner bound for Europe when he falls overboard and is rescued by Manuel who takes him aboard a New England fishing schooner captained by Disko. He is immediately put to work alongside the Captains’ son, Dan. The challenges that he faces and his slow and difficult mastery of new skills changes the boy from a brat into a gallant and brave apprentice.

results.title: The Wicker man
results.creator_credit: Robin Hardy, Peter Snell and British Lion Film Productions
results.brief_description: A spell binding occult thriller by writer Anthony Shaffer. A policeman goes to a remote Scottish Island to investigate the disappearance of a local girl and discovers a society of modern pagans worshipping the ancient gods of Earth, Rain and Sun. They are led by a sinister overlord in erotic rituals and savage ceremonies of human sacrifice and weave a web of hedonistic pleasure and terror around the puritanical, holier-than-thou policeman. When he finally discovers what happened to the girl, his nightmare is only just beginning!

results.title: Them!
results.creator_credit: Gordon Douglas, David Weisbart and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Man split the atom to create the ultimate weapon not realising he would also create Them! The terror begins in the New Mexico desert when a patrolman (James Whitmore) discovers a ransacked General Store with the cash drawers untouched, the sugar supply missing and a battered corpse containing enough formic acid to kill 20 men. An FBI official and a fuddy-duddy entomologist (Edmund Gwenn) attempt to unravel the mystery. What they discover strikes terror from coast to coast: man’s atomic testing has spawned rampaging hordes of giant radiation-mutated ants, 12 feet long and capable of lifting tons. These mutants bypass the larval stage and come directly from the egg - ready to kill. In an epic death struggle, the formidable formicidae are trapped in the 700-mile storm drain network beneath fear-stricken Los Angeles and eventually beaten. A generation of films about radioactive creatures have approximated the terror but none have equalled the artistry of Them! with Academy Award nominated special effects (1954). Co-starring Joan Weldon, James Arness and Onslow Stevens. Fess Parker has a small but memorable role and look quickly for Leonard Nimoy at a teletype machine.

results.title: Trust
results.creator_credit: Hal Hartley, Bruce Weiss, True Fiction Pictures and Zenith
results.brief_description: Hal Hartley cemented his reputation as one of America’s leading independent filmmakers with this sometimes very black but always emotionally involving comedy about two misfits who fall in love. Adrienne Shelley is Maria, a woman constantly bullied by her lovers and her family, who falls in love with a drifter, Matthew (Martin Donovan). Matthew has been hurt too often in the past to trust women easily and his testing of Maria’s love becomes more and more fantastic and dangerous as the relationship progresses. Only through challenging her to risk life for him does Matthew believe he can be assured of her love. How these two damaged people get together, learn to have faith again, and how they remove themselves from the absurd complications of life in the late 20th Century is the theme of this fresh, contemporary and engaging film.

results.title: Simple men
results.creator_credit: Hal Hartley, Ted Hope and True Fiction Pictures
results.brief_description: Two brothers are searching for their terrorist father who has escaped from goal. The trail leads them to a small town on Long Island where they meet a community of people who give them a refreshingly different view of their father. The ensuing complications between the brothers, as they battle to discover the truth of their family history, results in their confiding and falling in love with two very independent women. In order to defend their father’s honour, they all become involved in a battle with the police that leads to a surprising resolution. From this simple plot Hartley creates an eccentric film about history and relationships that challenges the viewer’s stereotypes of heterosexual romance. As is typical in Hartley’s work, the ensemble cast is universally excellent, including Martin Donovan, Robert Burke and Bill Sage. Special mention must go to Elina Lowensohn who plays a Romanian immigrant who falls in love with one of the brothers. The Godardian scene in which she leads a dance to Sonic Youth’s song “Cool Thing” is one of the film’s highlights. The musical score is excellent.
